summary: This is a 2011 Supreme Court of Ghana decision in a matrimonial dispute between Dr. Owusu Afriyie Akoto (Appellant) and Adwoa Abrefi Akoto (Respondent), who married in 1974 and converted to a monogamous marriage in England in 1976. After the marriage broke down in 1997, both parties filed divorce petitions. The Respondent sought dissolution of marriage, declarations of joint beneficial ownership of properties in Ghana and the UK, custody of the minor child, maintenance, and a lump sum settlement. She succeeded in both the High Court and Court of Appeal. The Appellant appealed to the Supreme Court, challenging (1) the jurisdiction of Ghanaian courts over immovable properties in the UK, (2) the award of company-owned properties to the Respondent despite her not being a shareholder, and (3) the alleged excessiveness of the financial settlement. The Supreme Court upheld the lower courts' decisions, affirming jurisdiction under section 33 of the Matrimonial Causes Act, 1971 (Act 367) based on the presence of assets in Ghana and equitable principles. It also recognized the court's power to grant beneficial interests in company-held properties in matrimonial disputes and found the financial award just and not excessive.
verdict: The appeal was dismissed. The decisions of the High Court and Court of Appeal were upheld.
rationaleHighlights: The Supreme Court upheld the jurisdiction of Ghanaian courts to determine financial provisions in divorce cases involving foreign immovable property under equity and section 33 of Act 367.
The court affirmed that a spouse may be granted beneficial interest in properties held by a company even if not a shareholder, based on equitable principles.
The financial settlement in foreign currency was upheld as not excessive given the circumstances of the case.
